quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: What I love about Shreyas is that his insights are often framed in really memorable and interesting ways and they're often contrarian and not ideas that you've heard elsewhere.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights that the episode will challenge conventional PM wisdom with contrarian, memorable framing.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our chat, we focus on five topics and go deep on them.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets up a structured “five topics” format that practitioners can use to organize learning or team discussions.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We dig into why most execution problems are really strategy problems.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lens for diagnosing delivery issues by first questioning strategy rather than execution mechanics.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We look into the three levels of product work and how getting them wrong often leads to tension on your team.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a practical framework (“three levels of product work”) for reducing team friction by aligning on the right level.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Coda is an all in one doc that combines the best documents, spreadsheets, and apps in one place.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A concise product positioning statement that highlights a practical consolidation model for reducing tool sprawl.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over the years, I've seen Coda evolve from being a tool that makes teams more productive to one that also helps bring the best practices across the tech industry to life with an incredibly rich collection of templates and guides in the Coda Doc Gallery, including resources for many guests on this podcast, including Shreyas, Gokul, and Shishir, the CEO of Coda.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: An example of a product evolution strategy: moving from productivity tooling to codifying and distributing best practices via templates.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Some of the best teams out there like Pinterest, Spotify, Square, and Uber use Coda to run effectively and have published their templates for anyone to use.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Concrete social proof plus a reusable methodology angle (public templates) that practitioners can adopt or benchmark against.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're ping ponging between lots of documents and spreadsheets, make your life better and start using Coda.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Direct, actionable advice aimed at reducing context switching and operational friction in day-to-day work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Productboard can help you create a scalable, transparent and standardized process so your PMs understand what their customers really need and then prioritize the right features to build next.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A clear process model for product orgs: standardize customer understanding to drive prioritization decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Podcast format and Shreyas’s personal background
quotes.text: So we strategized about how to make this podcast as concretely useful and actionable for as many people as possible.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights an explicit “optimize for actionable usefulness” principle that practitioners can apply when designing content, meetings, or processes.

quotes.topic_title: Podcast format and Shreyas’s personal background
quotes.text: And so, we decided to do is instead of a regular interview where we talk about a lot of stuff, instead we're going to go deep on five of your ideas, teachings, lessons that you've shared on Twitter that have stuck with me, and I know have resonated with a lot of other people and we're going to call it the five big ideas from Shreyas Doshi.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a reusable format/framework (“go deep on five big ideas”) for structuring interviews, presentations, or retros to maximize depth over breadth.

quotes.topic_title: Podcast format and Shreyas’s personal background
quotes.text: So growing up, I saw him work on packaging and pricing.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A concrete example of early exposure to core product fundamentals (packaging + pricing) that many teams underemphasize compared to features.

quotes.topic_title: Podcast format and Shreyas’s personal background
quotes.text: So I grew up in that environment where the lines between what was my dad's business and our personal lives were very blurred.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A memorable observation about how deeply work can permeate life—useful for reflecting on founder/operator tradeoffs and boundaries.

quotes.topic_title: Podcast format and Shreyas’s personal background
quotes.text: Partly, I think because in India back then, if you were good at science and mathematics, you would usually take up engineering.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A specific cultural datapoint about career-path defaulting that can inform how leaders think about talent pipelines and “why people choose what they choose.”

quotes.topic_title: From engineering to product management
quotes.text: For about a year, I was doing the product job without having the title and I was also the engineer. So I was in this great state where I'd figure out what needed to be built and I would just build it myself.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Highlights a practical way to transition into PM by taking on product responsibilities before formally changing roles.

quotes.topic_title: From engineering to product management
quotes.text: And at some point during that one year, I realized that while I was a good engineer, I was perhaps a top 20% engineer. I realized that I would never be a great engineer, that I would never be a top 10% engineer because I saw those engineers, the fortune of working with them, and I just could tell that I couldn't be that.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A memorable comparative-advantage lens for choosing a career path based on where you can excel relative to peers.

quotes.topic_title: From engineering to product management
quotes.text: I think it might be a common occurrence because engineering is a really great job, particularly on empowered teams, as an engineer, you can do a lot. You don't have to just write code, but you can do a lot.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Reframes engineering as a broad, high-leverage role on empowered teams—useful for PM-aspirants evaluating where to start.

quotes.topic_title: From engineering to product management
quotes.text: And I often respond with, "Tryout engineering because, again, in many companies, fortunately these days you can do a lot more than just the core engineering job. And so you get exposure to many different things. And once you do that, you can decide what path to pick."
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Actionable career advice: use engineering as a low-regret entry point to gain product exposure before committing to PM.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Loudcloud/Opsware and high-caliber teams
quotes.text: Again, because even though I was hired as an engineer, the non-engineer task I was given was to manage a relationship with Opsware because the way that split worked is EDS would use Opswares data center automation technology, and my team was responsible for deploying and supporting that technology for EDS.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Highlights a practical model of PM-adjacent work: owning cross-company/vendor relationships as part of delivering outcomes, even from a non-PM role.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Loudcloud/Opsware and high-caliber teams
quotes.text: And so, I was given this role of managing the vendor relationship and I have no idea. I'm in my early 20s, I have no idea how to manage vendor relationships, but I ended up doing that.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career lesson: high-growth environments often require stepping into ambiguous responsibilities before you feel ready.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Loudcloud/Opsware and high-caliber teams
quotes.text: And that was my first experience of what a really highly talented and energetic team looks like, both on the Opsware side, like I said, I worked with a number of people there, but also on the former Loudcloud side who were my team members.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Points to a key benchmark for practitioners: learning to recognize the traits of exceptional teams through direct exposure.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Loudcloud/Opsware and high-caliber teams
quotes.text: And that magic, a very high caliber team, people who really great at their job and brought high degree of energy and collaboration to their work.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A memorable definition of “high-caliber teams” that practitioners can use as a hiring and team-health rubric (skill + energy + collaboration).

quotes.topic_title: Key takeaways from Yahoo, Google, Twitter, Stripe
quotes.text: So this is one of those things where sometimes it's painful in the short-term, even though it might actually be the right answer over the long-term.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A practical reminder for product leaders to tolerate short-term backlash when executing migrations or platform unification that pays off long-term.

quotes.topic_title: Key takeaways from Yahoo, Google, Twitter, Stripe
quotes.text: Google, I think the main thing I learned was the power of thinking really big.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A simple but operationalizable principle: set ambition as a default operating mode rather than a special-case exercise.

quotes.topic_title: Key takeaways from Yahoo, Google, Twitter, Stripe
quotes.text: there was this unwritten rule of thumb that, hey, if it's not going to generate more than $100 million in revenue, it's not worth talking about it.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A concrete prioritization threshold illustrating how scale changes what opportunities are worth pursuing.

quotes.topic_title: Key takeaways from Yahoo, Google, Twitter, Stripe
quotes.text: So that tendency to think about, well, yes, there is $10 million business here, but can we make it $100 million business? Or there is a $1 million business here, can we make it a $10 million business? What does it take to make it bigger is a habit, I think, that got ingrained for me at Google.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A repeatable scaling framework: explicitly ask what would need to change to 10x an opportunity before committing resources.

quotes.topic_title: Key takeaways from Yahoo, Google, Twitter, Stripe
quotes.text: at Stripe, I think the main thing I took away was that when you combine high energy sound judgment, low ego and small teams, you just get magic.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A team-design formula leaders can apply when hiring, structuring teams, and setting cultural norms for execution speed and quality.

quotes.topic_title: Founder lessons: Larry, Jack, Patrick, John
quotes.text: And I think particularly if I were to pick one thing, I really appreciated Larry's strategic insight and particularly his ability to simulate the future to make better decisions.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A practical mental model for leaders: use future-simulation to improve present-day strategic decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Founder lessons: Larry, Jack, Patrick, John
quotes.text: And I remember very distinctly, he asked me one question which was something to the effect of, how does this make our users love Twitter more?
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A simple, high-leverage question that cuts through metrics and strategy debates to refocus on user value.

quotes.topic_title: Founder lessons: Larry, Jack, Patrick, John
quotes.text: And that got me thinking a lot about how I need to reframe my approach to basically separate the effort involved in building something with the effort you want to put behind talking about said thing.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive marketing/product lesson: what’s hard to build isn’t necessarily what’s best to highlight to customers.

quotes.topic_title: Founder lessons: Larry, Jack, Patrick, John
quotes.text: So instead of talking about values, I saw both of them just live the values that they wanted the company to replicate, especially as the company was scaling.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A culture-building methodology: values spread more reliably through consistent example than through stated principles.

quotes.topic_title: Founder lessons: Larry, Jack, Patrick, John
quotes.text: And I think that consistency spoke louder than anything that you might write on a poster on the office walls.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A memorable reminder that culture is shaped by repeated behavior, not slogans—useful for scaling organizations.

quotes.topic_title: Big Idea #1: Pre-mortems to prevent failures
quotes.text: And the idea is simple, which is when you are working on an important project or initiative, you get together with your team early on in the products or the projects' life to see in advance what could go wrong.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Defines the pre-mortem as an early, proactive risk-discovery ritual teams can implement on any important initiative.

quotes.topic_title: Big Idea #1: Pre-mortems to prevent failures
quotes.text: And the way I describe a pre-mortem is that if you do a pre-mortem right, you will not have to do an ugly post-mortem.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Memorable claim that reframes pre-mortems as a practical way to prevent painful failures rather than just analyze them afterward.

quotes.topic_title: Big Idea #1: Pre-mortems to prevent failures
quotes.text: The initial prompt is the genius, which is the prompt starts with, imagine this project that we are working on has failed six months from now, or this launch we are doing has miserably failed. Let's just all imagine that. Now, let's work backwards from there and ask ourselves what went wrong, what could have contributed to this utter failure.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Gives the exact facilitation prompt that makes pre-mortems work by forcing backward reasoning from a hypothetical failure.

quotes.topic_title: Big Idea #1: Pre-mortems to prevent failures
quotes.text: One is much greater psychological safety for team members to talk about things they're concerned about, but that they were just hesitant to bring up because nobody likes to be negative in modern organizations, everybody wants to be optimistic and positive.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Explains the mechanism—psychological safety—that makes the ritual effective at surfacing risks people otherwise suppress.

quotes.topic_title: Big Idea #1: Pre-mortems to prevent failures
quotes.text: So I have a specific approach, which is I ask the team to talk about three things. Each member on the team should bring up three things. One is a tiger.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Introduces a concrete shared-vocabulary framework (tiger/paper tiger/elephant) teams can use to categorize and discuss risks.

quotes.topic_title: How to run a pre-mortem meeting effectively
quotes.text: The main thing about a pre-mortem is to include people from every function that is going to be involved in, say, if you're doing a launch.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Highlights the core execution principle: pre-mortems work best when cross-functional stakeholders who will execute the launch are in the room.

quotes.topic_title: How to run a pre-mortem meeting effectively
quotes.text: And so, if it's a really large launch, sometimes I will separate it into two groups. One is everything related to the engineering side of things.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Provides a scalable methodology for big launches: split pre-mortems by engineering vs. go-to-market to surface different risk types.

quotes.topic_title: How to run a pre-mortem meeting effectively
quotes.text: And then I like doing these pre-mortems where we alternate between speaking and quiet time.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Gives a concrete facilitation tactic (silent writing + sharing) that improves idea generation and reduces groupthink.

quotes.topic_title: How to run a pre-mortem meeting effectively
quotes.text: And the one other innovation I added as I did this often was also, after people shared, I ask people to pick the tiger that they find more scary, but that somebody else mentioned, so not their own tiger, but some other tiger that somebody else mentioned that they found more scary.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Introduces a lightweight voting mechanism to prioritize risks and avoid bias toward one’s own concerns.

quotes.topic_title: How to run a pre-mortem meeting effectively
quotes.text: Whereas pre-mortem is a very inexpensive way to see these things because all it is is one meeting followed by some work that the leader needs to do to prioritize, followed by some mitigating actions, which you would've had to take anyway.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Makes the ROI case for pre-mortems as a low-cost, high-upside practice that prevents avoidable backlash and rework.

quotes.topic_title: Big Idea #2: LNO framework for PM time allocation
quotes.text: as a product manager or as anybody in a creative high impact high leverage role, all your tasks are not created equal, there are actually three type of tasks that you end up doing in such a role.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Introduces the core premise behind LNO: categorizing work by impact rather than treating all tasks uniformly.

quotes.topic_title: Big Idea #2: LNO framework for PM time allocation
quotes.text: So there are L tasks which are leverage tasks. And the L tasks are such that when you put in a certain amount of effort, you get 10X or 100X in return in terms of impact.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Defines “leverage tasks” with a memorable 10X/100X impact heuristic for prioritizing time.

quotes.topic_title: Big Idea #2: LNO framework for PM time allocation
quotes.text: it turns out that many people who are ambitious or are perfectionists like myself by default treat each of these types of tasks the same way, and therein lies the problem.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Highlights a counterproductive default behavior—applying perfectionism equally—that leads to misallocated effort.

quotes.topic_title: Big Idea #2: LNO framework for PM time allocation
quotes.text: So now, where does that more time come from because it cannot come from just working more hours? Well, it comes from spending less time on N tasks and O tasks.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Gives actionable guidance for creating capacity for high-leverage work by deliberately cutting neutral/overhead time.

quotes.topic_title: Big Idea #2: LNO framework for PM time allocation
quotes.text: something I realized is that the same type of activity can actually be either an L task or an N task or an O task.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Provides a nuanced mental model: classification depends on context and stakes, not the activity label itself.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Sprigg is a user research platform that makes getting user insights from your product as easy and fast as getting analytics.
quotes.speaker: Lenny (host)
quotes.context: Memorable positioning that frames user research as something teams can operationalize with the same speed/rigor as analytics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The best product and research teams at companies like Loom, Opendoor and Dropbox use Spriggs in product surveys to target specific users, start collecting insights and identify issues and opportunities related to activation, onboarding, engagement [inaudible 00:40:54].
quotes.speaker: Lenny (host)
quotes.context: Concrete examples of where in-product surveys can be applied across key lifecycle moments (activation/onboarding/engagement).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But I'm perhaps most excited about Sprigg's newest launch, which extends the power of the platform pre-launch and makes it possible to test mockups and prototypes with your own users in minutes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny (host)
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: rapid pre-launch validation by testing mockups/prototypes directly with existing users.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And with unlimited seats, you're able to invite anyone from your company to view and use insights generated by Sprigg.
quotes.speaker: Lenny (host)
quotes.context: Operational insight: broad access to research outputs helps scale customer understanding beyond a single team.

quotes.topic_title: Identifying true leverage tasks and beating procrastination
quotes.text: Yeah. So, turns out that the L tasks, PMs implicitly just deep down they know what their L tasks are, because those are the tasks that are bothering them the most because they are not doing them or because they're not doing them as well as they know they should.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic: the highest-leverage work is often identifiable by the persistent discomfort of avoidance.

quotes.topic_title: Identifying true leverage tasks and beating procrastination
quotes.text: The reason we procrastinate on these tasks are, one, because we know that they're L tasks, we know the impact they'll have, and we are a little scared.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Reframes procrastination as fear of high-impact work rather than poor time management.

quotes.topic_title: Identifying true leverage tasks and beating procrastination
quotes.text: Why many people procrastinate on strategy? Because deep down, they don't know if they can formulate a good strategy.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Pinpoints a root cause behind avoiding strategy work: fear of not having something valuable to say.

quotes.topic_title: Identifying true leverage tasks and beating procrastination
quotes.text: One is the idea of placebo productivity.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Introduces a named tactic/mental model for overcoming avoidance of leverage tasks.

quotes.topic_title: Identifying true leverage tasks and beating procrastination
quotes.text: The other is change of location. Nothing, for me, at least fights my procrastination for L tasks better than changing the place from which I'm working.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Actionable execution hack: use environmental change to trigger focus and complete high-leverage work.

quotes.topic_title: Big Idea #3 begins: Three levels of product work
quotes.text: Basically the three things that a PM should be focused on and how often when you're not aligned on what is most important to you and your team, it often leads to conflict.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical root cause of team tension: misalignment on which level of product work matters most.

quotes.topic_title: Big Idea #3 begins: Three levels of product work
quotes.text: We can all share what they are impact, execution and optics.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Names the three-level framework that can be used to diagnose and resolve product org misalignment.

quotes.topic_title: Big Idea #3 begins: Three levels of product work
quotes.text: This idea that there are three levels of product work, impact, execution, and optics. Once you understand it, it explains a lot of what you see on product teams and organizations in general.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Positions the framework as a high-leverage lens for interpreting recurring dynamics across product teams and orgs.

quotes.topic_title: Big Idea #3 begins: Three levels of product work
quotes.text: And as you're presenting what the plan is, obviously since this is a real world product, there's going to be some compromises that you're taking.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: A reminder that tradeoffs are inherent in real product plans—useful framing for stakeholder management and expectation-setting.

quotes.topic_title: Big Idea #3 begins: Three levels of product work
quotes.text: Maybe you ask your manager what happened and particularly you're wondering why couldn't the CEO see a very rational argument about why you can't do this at launch.
quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.context: Sets up a common, counterintuitive failure mode: rational explanations don’t always land in exec reviews, often due to differing priorities/levels.
